documentType: US Marshals Service Report of Investigation
summary: This document is a compilation of US Marshals Service investigation reports concerning Jeffrey Epstein's compliance with sex offender travel reporting requirements (International Megan's Law). It details witness interviews, investigative steps, and the closure of the case following Epstein's death. The reports include allegations of Epstein traveling with young girls and failing to report international destinations.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.role: Convicted sex offender, subject of investigation
persons.context: The primary subject of the US Marshals investigation for potential violations of International Megan's Law due to unreported international travel. He is described as a convicted sex offender who traveled frequently on a private jet.

persons.name: Senior Inspector (SI)
persons.role: US Marshals Senior Inspector conducting the investigation
persons.context: The lead investigator who conducted witness interviews, coordinated with the AUSA's office, and filed reports. The name is redacted.

persons.name: Supervisory Inspector (SI)
persons.context: Met with the Miami Herald reporter during an interview. The name is redacted.

persons.name: Miami Herald Reporter
persons.context: Provided information to US Marshals about potential witnesses, including an airport informant, a former employee of Epstein, a disgruntled attorney, and a former police chief.

persons.name: Air Traffic Controller Informant
persons.context: An informant who worked at an airport and reported observing Epstein disembark from his plane with young girls on multiple occasions between June/July and November 2018.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: The prosecutor in the US Virgin Islands with whom the Senior Inspector coordinated regarding MLAT requests and the eventual closure of the case after Epstein's death. The name is redacted.

connections.description: The informant witnessed Epstein getting off his plane with young girls at the airport where she worked.
The reporter received information from the air traffic controller informant about Epstein's activities.
The reporter provided tips and contact information for potential witnesses to the US Marshals investigator.
The Senior Inspector coordinated the investigation with the AUSA's office regarding legal requests and case strategy.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Conviction
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was convicted in Florida of procuring a person under the age of 18 for prostitution and sentenced to 13 months incarceration.

events.title: Epstein Reports Travel in USVI
events.description: Epstein visited the US Virgin Islands Department of Justice on St. Thomas and signed a Notification of Duty to Report travel.

events.title: Reported Travel to France
events.description: Epstein notified authorities of travel to France via his private jet (N212JE).

events.title: Unreported Travel to Vienna
events.description: Flight tracking data indicated Epstein's jet traveled to Vienna, Austria, a destination not listed on his travel notification form.

events.title: Unreported Travel to Monaco
events.description: Flight tracking data indicated Epstein's jet traveled to Monaco, a destination not listed on his travel notification form.

events.title: Interview with Miami Herald Reporter
events.description: US Marshals inspectors met with a Miami Herald reporter who provided leads on witnesses related to Epstein.

events.title: Interview with Air Traffic Controller
events.description: A Senior Inspector interviewed an air traffic controller informant by phone regarding observations of Epstein with young girls.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein committed suicide while in custody in New York.

events.title: Case Closure Decision
events.description: Following Epstein's death, the Senior Inspector spoke with the USVI AUSA's office and all parties agreed to drop the case, canceling all warrants and investigative activities.

keyFacts: The US Marshals were investigating Jeffrey Epstein for potential violations of International Megan's Law for failing to report all his international travel as a registered sex offender.

An air traffic controller informant reported witnessing Epstein get off his plane with young girls, some appearing to be as young as 11-12 years old, at an airport between June/July and November 2018.
Flight tracking data revealed Epstein's private jet traveled to Vienna, Austria and Monaco in March 2019, destinations he did not report to authorities as required.
A Miami Herald reporter provided investigators with leads, including information about an informant who saw girls board a helicopter from Epstein's island to his airplane.
The entire investigation was closed and all pending warrants and requests were canceled following Epstein's suicide on August 10, 2019.
